abstract.text: A scene that presents its content in an unbounded space.

inlineContent.text: Use an immersive space as a container for a view hierarchy that your app
presents. The hierarchy that you declare as the immersive space’s content
serves as a template for it:
If you want to create a bounded scene instead, use one of the types that
creates a window or a volume, like
or
By default, immersive spaces use the
style which
places virtual content in a person’s surroundings. You can select a
different style for the immersive space by adding the
scene modifier to the scene.
For example, you can completely control the visual
experience using the
immersion style:
You can change the immersion style after presenting the immersive space
by changing the modifier’s
input, although you can only use
one of the values that you specify in the modifier’s second parameter.
For any style of immersion, the other parts of your app’s interface —
namely its windows — remain visible. However, the immersion style
affects how windows interact with virtual objects in the environment:
For the
style, a virtual object obscures part
or all of a window that’s behind the object. Similarly, a window
obscures a virtual object that’s behind the window.
For other styles, windows always render in front of virtual content, no
matter how someone positions the window or the content. This helps people
to avoid losing track of windows behind virtual content when passthrough
is partially or completely off.
You can programmatically open an immersive space by giving it an identifier.
For example, you can label the solar system view from the previous example:
Elsewhere in your code, you use the
environment value to get the
instance of the
structure for a given
. You call the instance directly — for example, from a
button’s closure, like in the following code — using the identifier:
Mark the call to the action with
because it executes asynchronously.
When your app opens an immersive space, the system hides all other visible
apps. The system allows only one immersive space to be open at a time. Be
sure to close the open immersive space before opening another one.
You can dismiss an immersive space by calling the
action from the environment.
For example, you can define a button that dismisses an immersive space:
The dismiss action runs asynchronously, like the open action.
You don’t need to specify an identifier when dismissing an immersive space
because there can only be one immersive space open at a time.

content.text: Present an immersive space at launch

inlineContent.text: When an app launches, it opens an instance of the first scene
that’s listed in the app’s body. However, to open an immersive
space at launch, you need to provide additional configuration
information in your app’s
file. In particular, set the
key in the scene manifest to the value
To configure the style of the immersive space that opens at launch, add a
scene configuration to the scene session role. Use the
key together with a value that indicates one of the mixed, full, or
progressive styles. See the initial immersion style key for more
information.

SwiftUI-PageImage-card.png.alt: A black Swift logo on a swirly blue and purple background.

abstract.text: Declare the user interface and behavior for your app on every platform.
A scene that enables support for opening, creating, and saving documents.
A property wrapper that reads a value from a view’s environment.
An immersive space dismissal action stored in a view’s environment.
The displacement that the system applies to the immersive space when
moving the space away from its default position, in meters.
An action that presents an immersive space.
The styles that an immersive space can have.
An immersion style that displays unbounded content that completely
replaces passthrough video.
An immersion style that displays unbounded content intermixed with other
app content, along with passthrough video.
A scene that presents its content in an unbounded space.
Creates an immersive space.
Creates the immersive space for a specified type of presented data.
Creates an immersive space.
Creates the immersive space associated with the specified identifier.
Creates the immersive space associated with an identifier for a
specified type of presented data.
Creates the immersive space associated with an identifier for a
specified type of presented data, and a default value, if the data is
not set.
A type that you can use as the content of an immersive space.
A result builder for composing a collection of immersive space elements.
Immersive space content that uses a SwiftUI view hierarchy as the
content.
An action that presents an immersive space.
A part of an app’s user interface with a life cycle managed by the
system.
Sets the style for an immersive space.
A scene that presents a group of identically structured windows.
The preferred initial scene session role for your app.
Configurations for scenes you use to display SwiftUI content in an immersive space.
Provide a preferred initial scene style for an immersive space scene.
A type that can encode itself to an external representation.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can decode itself from an external representation.
